Award.AwardTitle: The evolutionary genetics of reinforcement: an empirical study in neotropical Costus
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the role that natural selection plays in the origin of species is a central goal of evolutionary biology. Population genetics theory shows that, in special circumstances, natural selection can reinforce reproductive barriers between recently diverged species living in the same geographic area, but this theory has not been adequately addressed with data from natural systems. This project examines the evolutionary genetics of this process in a rapidly speciating group of tropical plants for which prior research has found evidence of reinforcement of reproductive barriers. The research uses genetic mapping techniques to characterize the genetic basis of the traits and mechanisms that reproductively isolate two recently diverged species, field experiments to better understand the ecological consequences of those traits, and molecular markers to assess historical patterns of gene flow between the species.

The idea that natural selection can directly favor speciation is important, because it shows a direct link between the processes of adaptation and speciation and because it elucidates a route for diversification to occur without prolonged periods of geographic isolation. This research empirically addresses the circumstances under which selection can reinforce speciation in a comprehensive way that links ecological factors and the underlying genetic processes. The results will be broadly applicable to understanding how certain groups of organisms and geographic areas have diversified without long periods of time or geographic isolation. The project will train young scientists in molecular genetics and evolution, and provide opportunities for them to conduct field research in a tropical rainforest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The tropical rainforests of Central and South America have the highest plant diversity on the planet, and we know that many plant lineages in these regions are actively undergoing high rates of species formation. What are the evolutionary and ecological mechanisms underlying this extraordinary diversification? Although we know that in general, populations tend to evolve into new species after long periods in geographic isolation, for many of the these plant lineages, we find close relatives living in the same areas and somehow managing to coexist even though they have not had long periods of time to evolve differences that would prevent them from mating. In this project, we investigate one such pair of recently diverged plant species that co-occur in the lowland rainforests throughout Central and South America. These species, member of a genus of spiral gingers, live in habitats that are interspersed and share the same hummingbird pollinators. Our previous work on these species has shown that differences in floral morphology that determine what part of the hummingbirds’ bodies is used for transferring pollen and incompatibility between the stigma and pollen of the two species work together to prevent hybridization from occurring, even though partially fertile hybrids can be made in experimental crosses in the greenhouse. Moreover, these barriers that prevent hybridization in nature are stronger in sites where the species co-occur, compared to isolated portions of their geographic ranges. This pattern suggests that natural selection has strengthened, or reinforced, these barriers to prevent maladaptive hybridization from occurring, and may help to explain how such closely related plants are able to live in the same area but remain distinct.

 

Under this grant, we investigate the genetics underlying this reinforcement of reproductive barriers. We specifically ask: 1) how much hybridization and gene flow has there been between these species where they co-occur, in order to drive the reinforcement of reproductive barriers?, and 2) what is the genetic architecture of reproductive barriers (in terms of number of genetic loci, and the linkage among them in the genome) that has allowed hybridization between the species to lead to a strengthening of isolation instead of a breakdown of isolation with genetic recombination in regions where they co-occur? Although we empirically work on only two species, we hope that our results will inform general models and ideas about how speciation, and specifically reinforcement, occurs.

 

To determine how much hybridization and gene flow there has been between these species, we collected leaf tissue from populations of both species from throughout their geographic ranges from Mexico to Bolivia, including both isolated and co-occurring populations. We genotyped these samples at a standard set of genetic markers. We found that there is a low level of ongoing hybridization between the two species at some geographic locations where they co-occur, but that this hybridization does not result in much introgression, or mixing of the genomes. Our inference is that most first-generation hybrids are eliminated from the populations prior to successfully interbreeding with the parental species.
